author: Daniel Weeks
title: Solar, battery storage to dominate new electricity generation in 2024: EIA
text:
Solar and battery storage will make up a vast majority of new utility-scale electric-generating capacity projects expected this year, according to the latest US Energy Information Administration data.
 Developers and power plant owners plan to add 62.8 GW of capacity in 2024, the EIA said in a Feb. 15 report. This projection represents a 55% increase in added capacity compared to 2023, which saw 40.4 GW added, the most since 2003, according to the EIA.
81% of the new capacity will be made up by solar and battery storage projects, according to the data. The breakdown is as follows
New Capacity Gigawatts Percent of total Solar 36.4 58% Battery Storage 14.3 23% Wind 8.2 13% Natural gas 2.5 4% Nuclear 1.1 2% Other 0.2 less than 1% Source: EIA
EIA called the projected solar additions a record, saying projected additions in 2024 would nearly double last year's gains at 18.4 GW.
Battery storage is also set to set a record for annual capacity additions. Total battery storage in the US is expected to nearly double , to the existing 15.5 GW.
Wind capacity additions have slowed in the past two years, according to EIA data. The expected addition of 8.2 GW is a decrease from the over 14 GW added in both 2020 and 2021.
Natural gas capacity additions are at a 25-year low in 2024, the EIA said.
Finally, the added nuclear capacity originates from the fourth reactor at Georgia's Vogtle nuclear power plant.
Leading states
Texas and California are expected to see the highest number of new projects this year. 35% and 10% of new solar projects are slated in Texas and California, respectively.
The two states will also be the main drivers of battery storage growth, making up a combined 82% of new capacity this year, or 6.4 GW in Texas and 5.2 GW in California.
The states are the top two in operating battery storage capacity, with California at 8.3 GW and Texas at 5.1 GW, as of fourth quarter 2023, according to government filings and company announcements that S&P Global compiled.

author: Simon King
title: Cold weather: Temperatures drop as arctic air sweeps into UK
text:
The weekend is set to be bitterly cold, bringing "significant snow" and blizzard-like conditions, forecasters say. Temperatures drop across UK as arctic blast brings more snow
PA Media Parts of the UK - including Northern Ireland - have already seen snow this week
A cold arctic blast has swept into the UK, bringing widespread frost and more snow to parts of Scotland. Temperatures dropped overnight ahead of a bitterly cold weekend that could see "significant snow" and blizzard-like conditions. The whole of England is under amber health alerts - meaning there is a risk of a rise in deaths - with one local NHS service urging people to avoid going out early in the morning when the frost is thick. Yellow weather warnings for snow and ice are in place for most of England, Wales and Scotland between Saturday and Monday.
Snow fell overnight in northern areas of Scotland, with pictures sent in to BBC Weather Watchers showing a blanket of white in the Highlands and the north-east of the country. Cold conditions are forecast to continue into next week. It comes after much of the UK was lashed by strong winds and heavy rain, which led to widespread flooding across the north-west of England. A number of flood warnings and alerts stay in place in north-west England as a major clean-up operation continues after hundreds were evacuated from their homes.
Airthrey Princess/BBC Weather Watchers "A wee mini snowman built just after midnight in case the snow is gone when I awake," one person in Nairn in the Highlands told BBC Weather Watchers
JRDixon1984/BBC Weather Watchers Another photo from the outskirts of Aberdeen showed a thick layer of snowfall
Colder conditions bring to an end a run of unseasonably mild weather over the festive period, which saw highs of between 11C and 13C on Christmas Day. Temperatures are set to be around 5C below the early January average, with a wind chill making it feel even colder. The amber cold health alerts cover the whole of England but are not in place for the rest of the UK. The UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) issues the alerts when temperatures are‚Ä¶
Simon King

author: VNExplorer
title: 'It‚Äôs a big mess:' Driving instructors say insurance rates are too high
text: In our Speakers Quarter report, we're hearing from driving instructors who have a pretty important job teaching Canadians how to drive, but they say they can barely make ends meet After Imran Mubarak's long term job went bust. I had been working in a retail store for more than 15 years, but my job went off. He decided to get behind the wheel. Right now, as a driving instructor, I like to teach the new generation the proper way of driving. Like teaching them to avoid those bad habits that drive us all nuts. The left lanes for passing, yes, and right lane for driving. Right lane for driving. People don't understand that no, and that's another cause. Traffic jam. He loves what he does, but as a new instructor it's been a tough start. What are the challenges when it comes to cost of being a driving instructor? The bigger cost is the insurance. For him it's 900 bucks per month. They can't afford 900. Well, how much do you make in a month or just often driving? I'm I'm a brand new driver so right now I'm making around $2400 and that includes $700.00 for my gas and $900.00 for insurance. He's calling on the government to pressure the insurance industry to give new instructors like him a break. He understands his risk is higher but says it doesn't justify the cost. Otherwise, eventually we're not going to survive. He also wants the government to crack down on illegal instructors who he says are taking away business from it. They're not paying insurance. They didn't go to even college. I just have a spent four, $500 to do the their extra break in the car and start teaching the driving instructions, which is not good. It's illegal, it's not safe, it's not fair. City News reached out to Ontario's insurance regulators. They're looking into the concerns. Mubarak is hopeful him speaking out leads to change. Allowing him to continue doing what he loves. Would you like it that much to stay in it? Because I'm sure you could get a job and not have all those expenses. Yes, I'm expecting the government should beep into it and reduce the amount of insurance money and check on the illegal driving instructors so the industry will be back in the good hand. As always, if you have an issue, story or question you'd like us to look into, love to hear from you. Reach out by visiting the Speaker's Corner tab on the City News website. Pat Haney, City News.

author: Dan Diamond
title: America has a life expectancy crisis. But it‚Äôs not a political priority. | Stars and Stripes
text: [U.S.](https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/) America has a life expectancy crisis. But it‚Äôs not a political priority. The Washington Post December 28, 2023 The commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration had an urgent message last winter for his colleagues, brandishing data that life expectancy in the United States had fallen again ‚Äî the biggest two-year decline in a century. Robert Califf‚Äôs warning, summarized by three people with knowledge of the conversations, boiled down to this: Americans‚Äô life expectancy is going the wrong way. We‚Äôre the top health officials in the country. If we don‚Äôt fix this, who will? A year after Califf‚Äôs dire warnings, Americans‚Äô life expectancy decline remains a pressing public health problem ‚Äî but not a political priority. President Biden has not mentioned it in his remarks, according to a review of public statements; his Republican challengers have scarcely invoked it, either. In a survey of all 100 sitting senators, fewer than half acknowledged it was a public health problem. While recent federal data suggests that life expectancy ticked up in 2022, a partial rebound from the ravages of the coronavirus pandemic, no national strategy exists to reverse a years-long slide that has left the United States trailing peers, such as Canada and Germany, and rivals, such as China. ‚ÄúI wish that life expectancy or health span were a fundamental political issue in the 2024 presidential campaign,‚Äù said Dave A. Chokshi, a physician and public health professor who formerly served as health commissioner of New York. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not living the healthiest lives that we possibly could.‚Äù The Washington Post spoke with more than 100 public health experts, lawmakers and senior health officials, including 29 across the past three presidential administrations, who described the challenges of attempting to turn around the nation‚Äôs declining life expectancy. Those challenges include siloed operations that make it hard for public and private-sector officials to coordinate their efforts, a health-care payment system that does not reward preventive care and White House turnover that can interrupt national strategies. Many suggested the nation needed an effort that would transcend political administrations and inspire decades of commitment, with some comparing the goal of improving life expectancy to the United States‚Äô original moonshot. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre no longer an America that talks about building a national highway system or sending a man to the moon, and yet it‚Äôs that kind of reach and ambition that we need to have to tackle the declining longevity problem,‚Äù said Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.). Experts, officials and lawmakers acknowledged that a political pledge to reverse the nation‚Äôs life expectancy slide could quickly backfire, given the need to focus on long-term goals that might not be reflected in short-term progress reports. A politician attempting to improve life expectancy could be out of office by the time improvements were detected. ‚ÄúPoliticians, in general, haven‚Äôt wanted to engage on this because it feels kind of squishy and the solutions don‚Äôt seem clear,‚Äù said Ashish Jha, the dean of Brown University‚Äôs public health school who this year stepped down as the White House‚Äôs coordinator of the national covid response. In an interview, Califf confirmed he‚Äôd urged colleagues in ‚Äúso many‚Äù meetings to take action on America‚Äôs eroding life expectancy. The trend is ‚Äúquite alarming,‚Äù the FDA commissioner said, sitting in his office in White Oak, Md., where he oversees the nearly $7 billion agency that regulates drugs, food and other common products used by Americans. ‚ÄúAll of the leaders within the [Department of Health and Human Services] I‚Äôve talked with about this.‚Äù White House officials said the president and his team were focused on combating the ‚Äúdrivers‚Äù of life expectancy declines, pointing to efforts to reduce drug overdoses, create an office to prevent gun violence and other initiatives. A senior health official in the Biden administration said pledging to improve life expectancy itself ‚Äúwould have to be viewed as something for a legacy.‚Äù ‚ÄúMaybe a second-term priority for Biden,‚Äù said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to speak frankly about internal White House operations. No single reason explains why America‚Äôs life expectancy has declined, with chronic disease, poor nutrition, insufficient access to care and political decisions all linked to premature deaths. There also is no single strategy to turn it around ‚Äî and no agreement on how to do it. Some public health leaders and policymakers have called for sweeping reforms to how the health-care system operates, while others home in on discrete factors such as lethal drug overdoses, which have spiked in recent years and received considerable attention but are not solely responsible for the decline in life expectancy. The paralysis over how to address the nation‚Äôs declining life expectancy extends to Congress, where a handful of lawmakers ‚Äî mostly Democrats ‚Äî have repeatedly portrayed the slide as a crisis, but most other lawmakers have said little or nothing. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt talk about life expectancy, because it just makes it clear what kind of failed system we currently have,‚Äù said Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), who has repeatedly warned about the rise in premature deaths, including organizing a July 2021 Senate hearing on the issue. Just 11 of the panel‚Äôs 18 senators attended, several only briefly; just five asked questions. ‚ÄúI talk to other senators about life expectancy data and watch their eyes glaze over,‚Äù Warren said. The Post submitted questions about life expectancy to all 100 sitting senators, sending emails, placing calls and making visits to their offices. Forty-eight senators ‚Äî including 35 Democrats, 11 Republicans and two Independents ‚Äî said they agreed that declining life expectancy was a problem. Many of those lawmakers pointed to their own legislation intended to combat opioid misuse and address conditions such as cancer and other factors linked to causes of premature death. All told, the 48 senators cited more than 130 separate bills focused on health-care issues. Despite the flurry of legislation, the nation‚Äôs progress on life expectancy has stalled, with the United States increasingly falling behind other nations well before the pandemic. No senator has crafted a bill specifically intended to improve life expectancy or create goals for health leaders to reach. Lawmakers have also worked at cross purposes, with Republicans fighting Democrats‚Äô efforts to enact legislation linked to gains in life expectancy, including efforts to expand access to health coverage and curb access to guns. Sen. John Neely Kennedy (R-La.), whose state had the third-worst life expectancy in 2020, about 73 years, recently suggested that life expectancy would even go up for young Americans. ‚ÄúI mean, the life expectancy of the average American right now is about 77 years old. For people who are in their 20s, their life expectancy will probably be 85 to 90,‚Äù Kennedy said on ‚ÄúFox News Sunday‚Äù in March. His office did not respond to requests for comment. Other Republican senators or their staff suggested they did not have a view on the issue because the senator did not sit on a relevant committee. Sen. Jerry Moran (R-Kan.) has ‚Äúno jurisdiction over this issue,‚Äù his office wrote in response to questions about whether Moran had views on declining life expectancy. Moran, who sits on the Senate panel that determines funding for health agencies, has cast votes on numerous health-care matters, including repeatedly voting to repeal the Affordable Care Act. In the absence of national solutions, some officials pointed to local efforts such as a new initiative in New York, which has repeatedly pioneered public health improvements later copied across the country. City leaders in November pledged to raise New Yorkers‚Äô life expectancy to a record 83 years, saying a coordinated approach could prevent premature deaths. Ashwin Vasan, the city‚Äôs health commissioner, testified in front of the city council, urging members to pass a law requiring the city‚Äôs health commissioner ‚Äî including his successors ‚Äî to work toward shared public health goals. ‚ÄúThis is a test for government. And I really am hopeful that New York City can pass that test,‚Äù Vasan said after his testimony, standing outside New York‚Äôs city hall. ‚ÄòFurther and further behind‚Äô Life expectancy in the United States was once a source of national pride ‚Äî a reflection of civic improvements, medical advances and other investments that set the nation apart from other countries. ‚ÄúThe future of human longevity, especially for Americans, seems bright indeed,‚Äù then-Sen. Larry Craig (R-Idaho) proclaimed at a 2003 congressional hearing, where expert witnesses listed scientific and technological breakthroughs that they expected would soon push U.S. life expectancy past 80 years. But even the most optimistic expert at the panel warned that America‚Äôs prospects could dim. James Vaupel, director of the Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research, urged federal officials to immediately prioritize a ‚Äúreal mystery‚Äù: the emerging international gap in life expectancy. ‚ÄúThe United States is doing so well on so many fronts, but it‚Äôs falling further and further behind on this critically important [measure], life itself,‚Äù Vaupel warned the Senate panel, imploring officials to ‚Äúreally start worrying about this.‚Äù It would take about a decade before Vaupel‚Äôs warning was heeded. Policymakers instead were focused on a more urgent political priority related to life expectancy: the growing cost of having so many older Americans seeking services through programs such as Medicare and Social Security. So when the Obama administration and congressional Democrats hammered out legislation that would become the Affordable Care Act ‚Äî the sweeping 2010 law that expanded health coverage to millions of Americans and made other changes to the health system ‚Äî there was little fear life expectancy would decline. Bob Kocher, a venture capitalist who worked in the Obama White House as a health-care and economic aide, said one reason the crafters of the Affordable Care Act were so intent on ‚Äúbending the curve‚Äù on health spending ‚Äúwas our belief that life expectancy was going to keep going up for the foreseeable future.‚Äù By 2013, public health experts had begun issuing more prominent warnings about life expectancy, pointing to the rising number of opioid overdoses, suicides and other preventable deaths. Senior officials across the Obama, Trump and Biden administrations said they were aware of those concerns but that their focus was on improving discrete factors linked to life expectancy, not on the overall number. ‚ÄúEvery meeting at the VA was about ‚Äòlife expectancy,‚Äô but I can‚Äôt tell you we put charts on the wall of ‚Äòwhat‚Äôs the life expectancy of a veteran,‚Äô‚Äù said Robert A. McDonald, secretary of veterans affairs under President Barack Obama. The nation‚Äôs current top health official, Health and Human Services Secretary Xavier Becerra, told The Post he‚Äôs acutely aware of the life expectancy decline, calling it the ‚Äúbyproduct of some very serious problems‚Äù such as gun violence and drug overdoses. But he downplayed the need for a national strategy, saying there was no reason to declare a public health emergency as he has done with the coronavirus and opioid deaths, adding his agency lacked the power to reverse the trend. ‚ÄúWe are so disjointed as a health system in the country,‚Äù Becerra said, suggesting that the responsibility to address life expectancy fell on ‚Äúmany of us,‚Äù including state health directors. While Biden hasn‚Äôt directly addressed declining life expectancy, some of his rivals have invoked it on the campaign trail. ‚ÄúWe used to think that life expectancy was just going to keep going up, and that‚Äôs just not been the case,‚Äù Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R) said in a CNBC interview in August, linking the decline to the pandemic, drug overdoses and other causes that began years ago. The DeSantis campaign did not respond to a request for comment about how the Florida governor would reverse the trend if elected president. ‚ÄúIf we had regulatory agencies that were actually interested in looking at data, we would be trying to figure out why the all-cause mortality [for Americans] has increased,‚Äù Robert F. Kennedy Jr., running as an independent in the 2024 campaign, said in an interview with The Post this summer. ‚ÄúThese aren‚Äôt covid deaths.‚Äù Political commentator Matthew Yglesias has repeatedly urged politicians to focus on life expectancy, saying that America‚Äôs decline reveals systemic problems that leave the country at risk. ‚ÄúTackling America‚Äôs weirdly short life expectancy should be a priority,‚Äù Yglesias wrote in one 2022 post. Although Yglesias has fans within the Biden administration who have sought his counsel after he has written about traffic safety and crime, his appeals on life expectancy haven‚Äôt led to similar invitations. ‚ÄúI think it winds up being a harder topic for politicians to get their heads around,‚Äù he said, noting the array of factors that span agencies and administrations. Califf said he‚Äôs keenly aware of his agency‚Äôs limits when confronting life expectancy. FDA is one of the nation‚Äôs most powerful regulatory bodies ‚Äî its staff often tout that they oversee about 20 cents of every dollar spent by U.S. consumers ‚Äî and Califf is pursuing initiatives, such as banning menthol cigarettes and improving access to generic drugs, that fall in his agency‚Äôs purview. But FDA can‚Äôt control how hospitals and doctors get paid. It can‚Äôt craft legislation, such as curbing access to firearms. ‚ÄúThe highest cause of death in children is guns. That‚Äôs a fact,‚Äù Califf said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not something FDA can do something about.‚Äù ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a hard sell‚Äô In Congress, a handful of members have insisted that lawmakers must focus on life expectancy, saying it‚Äôs a core responsibility. ‚ÄúSometimes, we may, in the midst of our work, lose sight of the big picture . . . to create a nation in which the people in the United States can live long, healthy, happy and productive life,‚Äù Sanders said at the 2021 Senate hearing he convened on lagging life expectancy. There is a notable partisan split in how members of Congress view life expectancy and whether they say urgent action is needed. Just 11 of the Senate‚Äôs 49 Republicans told The Post they believed that declining life expectancy was a public health problem. The lawmakers who portray the recent decline as a crisis are often Democrats from states with the highest life expectancy ‚Äî such as Massachusetts (79 years in 2020, according to federal data) and Vermont (78.8 years). Meanwhile, GOP lawmakers representing some of the states with the lowest life expectancy ‚Äî Mississippi (71.9 years), West Virginia (72.8 years) and Kentucky (73.5 years) ‚Äî declined to comment or did not respond to repeated questions about whether the issue represents a public health problem. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a hard sell with senators who live in some of the lowest longevity states. And it breaks my heart,‚Äù Warren said. A further complication: Senators concerned about declining life expectancy offer radically different prescriptions for fixing it. Alabama Sen. Tommy Tuberville ‚Äî one of the few Republicans whose office said he was ‚Äúdeeply concerned about this trend‚Äù ‚Äî linked America‚Äôs decline to drug overdoses, suicides and alcoholism. ‚ÄúThe facts show clearly that this is being driven largely by an increase in deaths of despair, with fentanyl overdoses being the leading cause of death for Americans 18 to 45,‚Äù Tuberville spokesman Steven Stafford said in a statement, pointing to legislation to improve mental health funding and secure the Southern border. In comparison, Sanders has repeatedly called for sweeping reforms, insisting in an interview that ‚Äúa failed health-care system is tied into a corrupt political system dominated by enormously powerful corporate interests.‚Äù Even Democrats in neighboring states offered significantly different diagnoses. In the eyes of Rhode Island Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse (D), the No. 1 cause of America‚Äôs life expectancy problem is clear: broken payment incentives for doctors and hospitals. But Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) traced the life expectancy decline to loneliness. ‚ÄúAmericans are just much less physically and spiritually healthy than they have been in a long time,‚Äù said Murphy, who has proposed a bill to create a White House office of social connection. Ten senators singled out the burden of chronic disease, echoing The Post‚Äôs own review, which found that among people younger than 65, chronic illness erases more than twice as many years of life as all the overdoses, homicides, suicides and car accidents combined. New York‚Äôs state of mind In New York, officials are trying to put a framework around those often abstract challenges. Vasan urged the City Council in November to support HealthyNYC, his agency‚Äôs initiative backed by Mayor Eric Adams (D) that seeks to avert about 7,300 premature deaths by 2030. ‚ÄúWe want New Yorkers to experience more birthdays, weddings and graduations, more holidays and holy days, more life lived,‚Äù Vasan told the lawmakers, citing targets for reducing chronic diseases, cancers and other drivers of premature death. Council members are considering legislation to ensure that future leaders stick to the commitments ‚Äî a suddenly urgent need with Adams embroiled in a fundraising scandal. ‚ÄúWe wanted this to be something that outlives us, that actually helps people,‚Äù said Lynn Schulman, chair of the City Council‚Äôs health committee. Vasan and Schulman said HealthyNYC can be a template for other cities ‚Äî the latest effort in New York‚Äôs long history of trying to tackle life expectancy. Under former mayor Mike Bloomberg, the city raised cigarette taxes, banned smoking in workplaces and attempted to limit sale of large sugary drinks. When Bloomberg left office in 2013, New Yorkers‚Äô projected life expectancy was 81.1 years ‚Äî more than two years longer than the national average ‚Äî compared with 77.9 years when he took office in 2001. ‚ÄúIf you want to live longer, you could move to New York ‚Äî or just vote for me,‚Äù Bloomberg said in a speech to Democratic voters during his short-lived 2020 presidential campaign. (Public health experts have cautioned that it may take decades to fully understand the link between Bloomberg‚Äôs initiatives and longer life expectancy.) But Bloomberg‚Äôs efforts provoked backlash from food-makers, industry groups and some elected officials. Even as New York took steps a decade ago to limit salt and soda consumption, GOP lawmakers in other states crafted legislation to prevent their own local leaders from taking similar steps. The Bloomberg legacy ‚Äúis not a torch anyone has really wanted to carry,‚Äù said Yglesias, warning that the former mayor‚Äôs public heath agenda would be politically difficult to replicate elsewhere. ‚ÄúConservatives really don‚Äôt like it. ... I think it‚Äôs fallen out of style on the left as well.‚Äù Sanders, who has spent years pushing for sweeping changes to America‚Äôs health system and economy, said Washington‚Äôs work to boost life expectancy could begin with a simple framing device. ‚ÄúThe administration, the Congress should have upon their wall, a chart which says ... ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs our life expectancy now [and] how do we get up to the rest of the world?‚Äô ‚Äù Sanders said. He pointed to Norway‚Äôs life expectancy of more than 83 years. ‚ÄúThat should be our goal.‚Äù Dan Keating contributed to this report.

author: MasterChof
title: #30 Estudiantes de Oxford y Cambridge acampan frente a sus universidades en solidaridad con Gaza y prometen que 'no se mover√°n' hasta que se cumplan sus demandas [ENG]

author: @Salis bin Perwaiz
title: Dr Shahnawaz Kunbhar was shot dead in staged encounter: inquiry report
text: The members of the inquiry committee formed to investigate Dr Shahnawaz Kunbhar‚Äôs death is of the unanimous opinion that the Mirpurkhas police had killed him in a staged encounter and failed to give it legal cover. They said that based on all the information already available as well as that was collected by the committee from different sources, they found that the Umerkot police had arrested Dr Kunbhar in Karachi and handed him over to the Mirpurkhas police the same day. They lamented that this illegal police action brought a very bad name to the Sindh police. They recommended that the victim‚Äôs family record their statements and lodge a murder FIR. They also recommended strict departmental action against all the officers involved. According to the committee‚Äôs findings, on September 17 the Umerkot police received reports about allegedly blasphemous social media activities of Dr Kunbhar, a resident of the Janhero village and a senior medical officer (BS-18) at the Umerkot District Headquarters Hospital (DHQ). As the news about the alleged blasphemy spread, a large number of people gathered in the Umerkot city to protest and riot. The main target of their aggression was the police because the alleged suspect was at large. The mob also set ablaze a police van and damaged other police vehicles. An FIR was later lodged against the doctor on the complaint of cleric Sabir Ali at the Umerkot Taluka police station, while another FIR was lodged against the rioters at the Umerkot City police station. The inquiry report states that pressure from clerics and the public was mounting on the police and an ultimatum of 48 hours had been given for arresting Dr Kunbhar. On the night of September 17 the Umerkot SSP received information that the doctor had been traced through his mobile phone to be in the Matiari district, following which the officer tasked his reader, SI Abdul Sattar, to arrest the man. Led by SI Sattar, an Umerkot police team comprising PCs Nawab Ali Samejo, Amanullah, Nadeem Khoso, Shah Muhammad, Irfan Shahani, Mashuq Ali and Atta Hussain (driver) left in the SSP‚Äôs escort van and a private car (a Cultus with registration No. BFK-404). Meanwhile, the mobile phone locator team of the Shaheed Benazirabad (SBA) Range was asked to assist the Umerkot police team. At 4:15am on September 18 SI Sattar reached Hyderabad and contacted the locator team, who joined them. The doctor‚Äôs mobile phone was switched off, so no action was taken. Later, they received information that the location of his phone was in Karachi. At 7:30am SI Sattar and the locator team proceeded to Karachi on the directions of the Umerkot SSP. They first reached the Garden area in Karachi and then the Saddar locality to trace the alleged suspect and a B-party number who was in contact with the doctor, but both their phones were switched off. At 11am SI Sattar received information about another mobile number of the doctor in the Tariq Road area, so they proceeded there with the locator team, but again the phone was switched off, so they returned to Lyari‚Äôs Baghdadi police station. Around 2pm a video clip of Dr Kunbhar surfaced on social media in which he claimed to be staying at a hotel. SI Sattar then checked the police app Hotel Eye to check the alleged suspect‚Äôs status. The app showed multiple entries going back many months of various hotels of Lyari where the doctor had stayed previously. Most of these hotels were around the Baghdadi police station. There was no current entry in Hotel Eye, so the SI went to the nearby Gul Balochistan hotel, where Dr Kunbhar had stayed in February. The hotel management recognised the doctor‚Äôs picture and confirmed his previous visits. SI Sattar showed the management the video clip to ascertain the hotel in it. An employee, Sanaullah Jamali, recognised the hotel as Pak-Qatar and an employee visible in the video. The police team went to the Pak-Qatar hotel, which was in the same neighbourhood, entering the establishment at 3:30pm. They started searching for him one room at a time. When SI Sattar reached room No. 304, Dr Kunbhar opened it. The officer recognised him and introduced himself. The alleged suspect had checked in at the hotel at 1:20pm that day. The SI talked to Dr Kunbhar and persuaded him to accompany the police, assuring him of secured transport to Umerkot. At 4:25pm the doctor was taken into police custody by SI Sattar with the team of the Umerkot police. They had covered the man‚Äôs face with a cloth. SI Sattar informed the Umerkot SSP about the detention. The senior officer ordered the SI to proceed back to Umerkot without any delay and without informing the Baghdadi police station. The Umerkot police team immediately left the area, and informed the locator team to go back to their district SBA because there was no further need of them. SI Sattar was in constant contact with the Umerkot SSP. At 7:45pm, when they were near Hyderabad, SI Sattar was directed by the Umerkot SSP to hand over the doctor‚Äôs custody to the Mirpurkhas police because the situation in Umerkot was tense. The SSP directed the SI to stay at the Jhamrao checkpoint to hand over the alleged suspect to the Mirpurkhas police. At 9:26pm the Umerkot police stopped near the checkpoint. A white police Vigo arrived to taken the doctor‚Äôs custody, then left. The Umerkot police team also left, took a tea break at the Madina Hotel on the Hyderabad-Mirpurkhas highway, then left for Umerkot. The Mirpurkhas Toll Plaza cameras show the Mirpurkhas SSP‚Äôs official white Vigo (No. SPF-851) going out at 9:19pm and returning at 9:30pm. The CCTV cameras do not show any other vehicle with such a description crossing that road in that particular time period. At 10:50pm the Mirpurkhas CIA police carrying the doctor left Mirpurkhas in a van (No. SPF-659) and at 12:18am on September 19 reached the Sabzal stop, in the jurisdiction of the Sindhri police station, where the SHO, Inspector Niaz Khoso, along with his staff, in police vehicle (No. SPB-671) joined them. At around 12:20am Dr Kunbhar was killed in a staged police encounter in the jurisdiction of the Sindhri police station, Mirpurkhas. Police found a mobile phone, a CNIC and Rs1,000 on the doctor. At 1:20am the deceased was shifted to the DHQ Civil Hospital Mirpurkhas by the Mirpurkhas CIA van. At 4:30am FIRs were registered at the Sindhri police station by the then SHO. After the completion of the post-mortem examination, the body was taken in an ambulance to Umerkot for the funeral, escorted by the Mirpurkhas CIA police and the Umerkot police. When the body reached Janhero, an angry prevented the ambulance from entering. The body was then shifted into a private car and taken to a secluded land of the Kunbhar family. Another mob gathered there and snatched the body in the presence of the police and the family. The mob set the body on fire. The family and the police took the half burnt body and shifted it to another remote place, where the burial took place. A large number of people gathered at the Mirpurkhas DIG and SSP‚Äôs office to celebrate Dr Kunbhar‚Äôs death. The police officers were hailed as heroes and praised for their action. Videos circulating on social media showed the police officers accepting compliments. This reaction caused an outrage and condemnation by liberal, secular and human rights activists on electronic and social media. Subsequently, the Sindh government ordered an inquiry committee to be formed. Meanwhile, the Mirpurkhas DIG and SSP, and other police officers concerned were suspended. On Thursday Home Minister Ziaul Hassan Lanjar held a press conference at the Directorate of Social Media‚Äôs office, where he said the Mirpurkhas DIG was removed from his post, and replaced by Zubair Dreshak. He said the Umerkot SSP and the Mirpurkhas SSP had also been removed from their positions. Lanjar said that a comprehensive 31-page report had been prepared after investigating all the aspects of the tragedy. ‚ÄúBased on the report, we‚Äôre ordering FIRs to be registered against the officers involved,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúIf the victim‚Äôs family doesn‚Äôt file a case, the Sindh government will pursue it. No matter how influential or senior an officer is, we‚Äôll hold everybody accountable.‚Äù The minister made the assurance that legal action is being taken against the officers involved in the incident. He hoped that investigations into Dr Kunbhar‚Äôs social media posts would reveal more facts. author: Nick Schultz
title: Browns WR Elijah Moore evaluated for concussion after scary injury on TNF
text: Cleveland Browns wide receiver Elijah Moore is being evaluated for a concussion after a scary injury in the second quarter Thursday night. He hit the turf hard after catching a pass from Joe Flacco , and he immediately headed the blue medical tent with some help. Moore was having a big game at the time of his injury, hauling in five receptions for 61 yards and a touchdown. After spending some time in the tent, he walked back to the Cleveland locker room for further evaluation. Moore is having a career year in his first season with the Browns. He had new career-highs in receptions (54) and yards (579), but only had one touchdown to his name. He spent the last two years with the Jets before making his way to Cleveland. The Browns were down a key playmaker for Thursday night‚Äôs matchup. Wide receiver Amari Cooper appeared to tweak his injury during warmups, and he was ruled out as a result. That meant Moore and others would have to step up. If he‚Äôs unable to go, though, it‚Äôll be next man up for Cleveland. With Joe Flacco at QB, Browns are rolling with playoffs approaching The Browns have put together an impressive stretch lately since Flacco took the reins at quarterback. They entered Thursday‚Äôs game 3-1 with the former Baltimore Raven under center, and quickly took control against the struggling Jets. Cleveland struck first when Flacco found Jerome Ford for a 7-yard touchdown and found pay dirt again when Kareem Hunt ran in a score. After Hickman‚Äôs pick-six, the Browns added to their lead again when Flacco hit Elijah Moore for a touchdown to make it a 27-7 lead in the second quarter. It was all Cleveland in the first half as the Browns took a 34-17 lead into halftime ‚Äî and, you could say, it was an elite start for Flacco. He completed 16 of 22 passes for 296 yards and three touchdowns through the first two quarters. Entering Thursday night, Flacco was averaging more than 325 yards per game and his only loss came against the Los Angeles Rams in his first game with the Browns. Then, Cleveland started its three-game win streak with a 31-26 victory over the Jacksonville Jaguars. The Browns followed that up with a 20-17 comeback victory over the Chicago Bears behind 374 yards from Flacco. With a talented defense, things are getting interesting in Cleveland as fans start to set their sights on a possible playoff appearance. The Browns entered TNF as the No. 5 seed in the AFC.

author: Loreto Aguilera
title: Aplicaci√≥n ‚ÄúActuapp‚Äù lanzada por Fundaci√≥n Iguales con apoyo UdeC permitir√° denunciar situaciones de discriminaci√≥n
text:
Aplicaci√≥n ‚ÄúActuapp‚Äù lanzada por Fundaci√≥n Iguales con apoyo UdeC permitir√° denunciar situaciones de discriminaci√≥n
Cr√©dito: Esteban Paredes Drake / Direcci√≥n de Comunicaciones
Iniciativa pionera en la regi√≥n busca contribuir a erradicar la discriminaci√≥n, entregando informaci√≥n sobre denuncias y sitios seguros de contenci√≥n. Todo esto en marco de un plan de acci√≥n regional contra la discriminaci√≥n de Fundaci√≥n Iguales.
‚ÄúEstudio Regional de Percepci√≥n de Discriminaci√≥n LGBTIQ+‚Äù es el nombre del an√°lisis, realizado por Fundaci√≥n Iguales, implementado por la Universidad de Concepci√≥n y financiado por el Gobierno Regional del Biob√≠o. La investigaci√≥n consign√≥ la opini√≥n de alrededor de 1800 personas, quienes expresaron en su mayor√≠a haber experimentado discriminaci√≥n por motivos como su orientaci√≥n sexual, de identidad o expresi√≥n de g√©nero.
No es la primera vez que Fundaci√≥n Iguales realiza este tipo de medici√≥n, cont√≥ su Directora ejecutiva, Mar√≠a Jos√© Cumplido. ‚ÄúLa regi√≥n del B√≠ob√≠o es la tercera regi√≥n con m√°s percepci√≥n de discriminaci√≥n por orientaci√≥n sexual e identidad de g√©nero. Es por eso que hemos tomado este desaf√≠o de seguridad regional y hemos venido a trabajar a la regi√≥n para crear una app muy innovadora que busca facilitar los procesos de denuncia‚Äù, detall√≥ Cumplido, argumentando que por medio de ¬´Actuapp¬ª las personas podr√°n denunciar si fueron v√≠ctimas o testigos de un hecho y el procedimiento pasar√° directamente a fiscal√≠a. ¬´Lo que estamos haciendo es llevar los procesos institucionales a tu bolsillo. Junto a eso estamos creando espacios seguros en toda la regi√≥n para que las personas tengan un lugar a donde ir para hacer contenidos, para ser ayudados y muchas veces para ser salvados‚Äù, puntualiz√≥.
Esta iniciativa est√° alineada con los objetivos estrat√©gicos de la Universidad de Concepci√≥n. As√≠ lo analiz√≥ la Vicerrectora de Relaciones Institucionales y Vinculaci√≥n con el Medio, Dra. Ximena Gauch√© Marchetti, identific√°ndolos como ‚Äúuna cultura de derechos humanos, la promoci√≥n del respeto a todas las diversidades y, por supuesto, la erradicaci√≥n de toda forma de discriminaci√≥n y violencia‚Äù, entre otros. La acad√©mica destaca el trabajo riguroso de la Unidad de Data Science UdeC, quienes apoyaron el trabajo de la fundaci√≥n con el an√°lisis de los datos del estudio.
‚ÄúActuapp‚Äù, junto con posibilitar la realizaci√≥n de denuncias a trav√©s del celular, entrega herramientas de apoyo, contenci√≥n y gu√≠a frente a actos discriminatorios. Contempla la identificaci√≥n de ‚Äúespacios seguros‚Äù para las y los usuarios, donde encontrar√°n personas capacitadas para contener a las v√≠ctimas y guiarlas en su denuncia. ‚ÄúNosotros lo que queremos es con esos datos llegar a los gobiernos locales y al gobierno central para hacer un plan de seguridad enfocado en la comunidad LGBTQ, que sea eficaz¬ª, adelant√≥ Cumplido, destacando que la aplicaci√≥n permitir√≠a tener un catastro fidedigno de las situaciones que vivan sus usuarios.
La Dra. Gauch√© recalc√≥ el trabajo pionero de la Universidad de Concepci√≥n, con la creaci√≥n de la Direcci√≥n de Equidad de G√©nero (Degyd) y la fiscal√≠a especializada, adem√°s de la colaboraci√≥n constante con iniciativas comprometidas con prevenir la discriminaci√≥n. Seg√∫n expres√≥, la UdeC trabaja en evitar, erradicar y sancionar estas actitudes dentro del quehacer universitario, pero destac√≥ que ‚Äúvivimos en una sociedad compleja, en tiempos muy cambiantes y por lo tanto deber√≠a ser un compromiso de toda la comunidad promover convivencias en todos los espacios p√∫blicos y privados‚Äù, puntualiz√≥.
Lanzamiento de Actuapp en el auditorio Universidad de Concepci√≥n (Esteban Paredes Drake / Direcci√≥n de Comunicaciones)
